title: Great Famine
description: The Great Famine hits Ireland.  It is estimated that during the famine (1845-1852), roughly one million people died and more than a million fled the country, with many leaving permanently.

title: Agrarian Crises in Scandinaiva
description: A series of agrarian crises (1870s-1890s) marked by falling grain prices, crop failures, and rural poverty increases Finnish and Swedish emigration to the United States.

title: German Unification
description: After decades of internal pressures, the German Empire emerges.  In the coming years, unification will have a dramatic impact on German people.

title: Long Depression
description: The Long Depression was a period of global economic recession from 1873 to 1899, with Europe and the United States being the most hard hit.  In the United States, more than 18,000 businesses went bankrupt and unemployment peaked in 1878 at 8.25%.

title: Famine of 1879
description: Sometimes referred to as the Mini-Famine, this event was part of the global Long Depression (1873-1899) and served as the catalyst for Irish migration to new lands, with many going overseas to the New World and the United States.

title: Steamships Revolutionize Ocean Travel
description: Steamship provide a cheaper, faster, and safer crossing experience.  Previous North Atlantic crossings by sailing ships could take between 30-60 days, depending on the winds and direction of travel.  By the time of the steamship, this time was reduced to about 14 days.  In 1860, the cost of an ocean passage was around $45; by the 1880s, the price had dropped to approximately $22.

title: Sweden Industrializes (1880-1910)
description: Sweden undergoes urbanization and industrialization, resulting in a period of short-term emigration. Emigration to the United States would peak in the 1880s due to slow growth, but would fall as job prospects improved internally.

title: Assassination of Tsar Alexander II
description: The death of Tsar Alexander II triggers a wave of repression and restrictions, worsening conditions for many groups and contributing to increased emigration.

title: Pogroms & Anti-Jewish Legislation
description: In the wake of the Tsar's assassination, violence and new discriminatory laws push large-scale Jewish migration to the United States.  These policies would remain in place until 1884.

title: Barberton Gold Rush
description: Gold discovered in South Africa, sparking a small rush from 1883-1886.  Many left when richer deposits were discovered nearby.

title: Foran Act Passed
description: With the passing of the Foran Act, companies are banned from importing foreign labor under contract, reducing organized mass recruitment from Europe.

title: Witwatersrand Gold Rush
description: Incredible gold deposits found in South Africa, leading to the Witwatersrand Gold Rush and the founding of Johannesburg.

title: Private Societies Promote Emigration
description: More than 60 private societies promote emigration amongst the English, Irish, and Scottish to the Dominions and United States.

title: Ruhr Mining Crisis
description: Falling coal prices and mine closures create unemployment in the Ruhr, contributing to renewed emigration from Germany.

title: German Industrial Expansion
description: Rapid industrialization creates thousands of urban industrial jobs.  This boom will significantly decrease emigration, while creating a surge in internal migration as more Germans move to the cities.

title: Murchison Gold Rush
description: Gold is discovered in Western Australia, lasting from 1891-1894.

title: Immigration Act of 1891
description: This act creates a federal immigration bureau (pre-Ellis Island) and excludes additional categories of migrants as "undesirable".

title: Coolgardie Gold Rush
description: More gold is discovered in Western Australia, lasting from 1892-1894.

title: Ellis Island Opens
description: The opening of Ellis Island centralizes U.S. immigrant processing; its scale and efficiency help accelerate mass migration volume through the 1890s and early 1900s.

title: Kalgoorlie Gold Rush
description: One of the richest goldfields ever found is discovered in Western Australia.  This mining operation is still running today.

title: Panic of 1893
description: The Panic of 1893 triggered a deep economic depression, reducing immigration demand as opportunities declined.

title: Sinking of the Elbe
description: The sinking of the German ocean liner SS Elbe kills 334 people on board, 20 minutes after the ship had collided with the British steamer SS Crathie in the North Sea.

title: Klondike Gold Rush
description: The discovery of gold in the Yukon draws tens of thousands to try their luck.  This gold rush would run from 1896-1899.

title: Atlin Gold Rush
description: More gold discovered in the Yukon and continues to bring people to Canada.  This gold rush would last from 1898-1900.

title: Royal Commmission on Alien Immigration
description: The Royal Commission of 1903 recommended the restriction and exclusion of certain groups of migrants.

title: Norway-Sweden Dissolution
description: Following years of rising nationalism, Norway and Sweden dissolve their union.

title: Aliens Act
description: Implementing many of the 1903 Commission's recommendations, the Home Office becomes responsible for controlling entry and may designate certain groups as "undesirable".

title: Russian Revolution of 1905
description: Widespread unrest, strikes, and political violence unsettle the empire, driving renewed emigration, especially from urban and Jewish communities.

title: Panic of 1907
description: While not as severe as the Panic of 1893, this economic downturn depressed economic opportunities.

title: Immigration Act of 1907
description: The act expands exclusion categories and leads to the creation of the Dillingham Commission to study "undesirable" immigration.

title: Porcupine Gold Rush
description: Gold is discovered in Northern Ontario.  While smaller than the previous two, this rush would continue from 1909-1911.

title: Dillingham Commission Report
description: A massive federal study concludes that “new immigration” from Southern/Eastern Europe is a threat, setting the political stage for later quota laws.

title: Titanic Sinks
description: April 1912 - Titanic sinks in the North Atlantic, reducing immigration demand.

title: World War I Begins
description: With the assassination of archduke Franz Ferdinand, Europe's tangle of alliances quickly devolves into a world war.

title: Emergency Quota Act
description: Introduced nationality-based quotas for immigrants.

title: Immigration Act
description: Further tightened immigration quotas by nationality.  With the passing of these two acts by the US Congress, the age of mass migration had come to an end.
